title: How do I keep my house from my ex husband chapter 7?
question: How and what does CA homestead exemption protect a home?
answers: Unless the mortgage was refinanced and put in your name only, which appears not to be the case, in filing bankruptcy, he will have to list the mortgage lender as a creditor since he is still responsible for the mortgage. This may cause problems for you with the mortgage lender. I urge you to meet directly with a bankruptcy attorney to discuss these issues in more detail.

The first question is whether the property is part of his "bankruptcy estate"; consult an attorney for details. If its not, then the liquidator (Chapter 7 Trustee) cannot cause its sale.
Ask: What Orders or Agreements exist in the Dissolution case that affect you are your EXs rights in the home? Was there consideration given to you to him in exchange for a conveyance by quit claim deed? When was the deed recorded?
Another question to consider is what the range of hypothetical equity; fair market value versus loan pay-off and cost of sale just in case the property is determined to be part of his bankruptcy estate?

As a borrower, the automatic stay in his BK7 will likely protect you from foreclosure for some or all all of the duration of his case (BK7s typically last 5 months).

The bigger problem is that you are in default; such that even if a Ch7 trustee does not seek to liquidate the property, the remedy of the mortgage company for your lack of payment is a forced foreclosure sale.

Ask: What loss mitigation options are available to you before or after his BK? Should you explore Ch7 and\or Chapter 13 yourself? If so, when?

Dealing with a property in distress is very challenging. Self help without specialized knowledge of bankruptcy, foreclosure and loan underwriting guidelines is risky With so much on the line, you would be wise to hire an attorney at LEAST for a strategy consultation and perhaps to help you navigate the duration of your journey.



It may be the case that your EX completes his Chapter 7

Please note, the exemption has no bearing on the mortgage, and is irrelevant to this question. The exemption protects your equity after deducting the mortgage from the value of the house.
As stated by other counsel, assuming the property was deeded to you 3 years ago through you divorce, there should be no major issues with the bankruptcy. (The trsutee might want a copy of the deed or the property division, but other than that, the transfer should be fine.)
The filing may discharge your husband's liability on the mortgage, but the lien remains on the house, and you are still liable. I assume you are in a Covid forbearance, so you need to reach an agreement with the lender to deal with the unmade payments. I am not addressing that portion of your question, as I don't know what you status is regarding those negotiations.
Once you have reached an agreement with the lender, keep making the payments and there will probably be no issues.

I agree with atty Granvold's analysis. Your ex-husband's bk 7 will not impact your ownership of the home. He must list all of his debts and all of his assets. Since he is still obligated to the mortgage lender, they will be notified. Since he deeded the property to you 3 years ago as part of a property settlement, he no longer has any legal or equitable interest in the home and will not have to include it as an asset. If you keep making the mortgage payments, you are not in danger of a foreclosure. You mentioned you are in a forbearance plan This suggests you are not current on your payments. If you perform fully with the terms of the forbearance plan you will eventually have to resume making regular mortgage payments. If you cannot pay the payments then, your lender may legally commence foreclosure (subject to any COVID limitations).

If house is provided to you in normal divorce as awarded to you 3 years ago I see no issues.

You should not assume anything at all except to meet with an attorney. What you read is true. If YOU filed bankruptcy and your house was worth 3 Million and you owed $400,000 only then you would lose it but be paid the homestead amount for example. Thus, keep paying your mortgage. You will receive as all creditors of his estate do a notice that he filed; you would if co-signor on mortgage debt or otherwise a creditor.

Thus, absent some issue when you transferred property to your name 3 years ago like fraud etc. I see no issues.

Transfers pursuant to divorce decrees ordered by State Courts occur all the time.

The safest thing if any question is to sit down with an experienced bankruptcy attorney even though you are not filing to discuss the issues. Find one here on AVVO to rest your stress involving your thoughts on your house. Good luck and thanks for asking here on AVVO.
